context: Ryan and Brad discuss ongoing financial harm caused by a mutual acquaintance. The exchange shows Ryan verifying facts, reconciling conflicting narratives, acknowledging prior patience, and supporting escalation only after confirming a repeated pattern of behavior.

text.msg:
FYI. we've spent the last 5+ months trying to deal with this. She finally gave up...
[I didn't say anything earlier because I was trying to give him every chance...]

We just talked about this last night and I mentioned I was going to reach out ask you personally...
[Dakota and I have been bit by this pattern of behavior...]

Ok. Yeah I can't begin to tell you how patient we've been...
[I feel bad for not only Donnie's family...]

Hey b, I hope you're doing well! I wanted to check in bc Wharton claimed this had all been paid...
[wanted to make sure in case we need to put any more pressure on him]

Hey. I appreciate you asking. He paid $4500 more...
There is a pattern, tbh
Sure, I'll give you a ring tomorrow!
There is a pattern. I suspect he's got some tricks

Yeah you don't have to convince me of much...
How much have you actually received so far? And when did he claim to have sent the last payment?
After pulling teeth, he has paid $5000 total until this weekend
(And we can just chat abt it tmrw)
He paid $4500 on Saturday... So he's paid $9500 of about $11500 now...

internal.thought: I already suspect a pattern based on my own experience, but I still want independent confirmation before pushing toward consequences.
I phrase my inquiry neutrally to avoid poisoning the well or signaling a predetermined outcome.
Once the facts align, I shift into evidence-gathering mode rather than emotional processing.
I affirm effective escalation tactics without celebrating harm; the goal is accountability, not punishment.
